awd_titl_txt: Femtosecond laser doping of silicon; a novel fabrication method for photovoltaics
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET-0754227
Mazur

Silicon is a desirable material for solar cells because of its abundance, non-toxicity, and existing manufacturing infrastructure; however, the high costs of producing silicon solar cells have prevented them from taking a larger role in the electricity generation market. Many proposals exist for achieving higher efficiencies in solar cells, as well as proposals for how to manufacture them less expensively.  Oftentimes, however, these goals are mutually exclusive.  The research we propose  using short, intense pulses of light to modify silicon and fabricate solar cells  could achieve both lower costs and higher efficiencies simultaneously.  Additionally, our research will make it possible to achieve these goals using silicon, an abundant material for which our society has tremendous engineering expertise (due to its ubiquitous use in electronics such as computers). As such, this research will help our country transition from fueling our energy needs via the carbon intensive combustion of fossil fuels to a renewable and sustainable future. 

Intellectual Merit: Prof. Eric Mazur's research group has developed a novel technique for constructing solar cells using very short pulses of laser light. Using these ultra-short laser pulses, we can endow silicon with remarkable optical properties, such as strong sensitivity to infrared colors of light that pass through a standard silicon solar cell without being absorbed. The focus of this research project is to leverage the group's expertise with lasers and solid-state materials to characterize this exciting new type of silicon and determine its promise as a new material in solar cells. During this project, a number of prototype silicon solar cells will be fabricated, including thin-film, multijunction, and nanoparticle-enhanced solar cells. These devices will represent the fruit of a novel fabrication technique that will lower costs and raise efficiencies for silicon-based solar cells. Our group has a well-proven record of scientific discovery and innovation, as evidenced by highly cited publications in peer reviewed journals, patents granted, and the launch of a rapidly growing start-up company based on technology discovered by the group.
Broader Impact: While our work will directly advance the state of solar cell technology, the proposed work will contribute to a better understanding of the exotic materials that are produced in the intense conditions of ultrashort laser pulses.  Additionally, our work will contribute to the education and training of future multidisciplinary scientists and engineers through research-based education of undergraduate and graduate students. Through our work with local high schools, NSF sponsored programs, and the high representation of women in our research group, we will broaden participation of underrepresented groups. Our extensive collaborations with academic and industrial partners around the world will enhance infrastructure for research, as will our participation in NSF-funded multi-user facilities. Finally, using the group's well-established program for integrating outreach and public education with research, this work will be broadly disseminated to the general public.

por.por_cntn:
Femtosecond laser doping of silicon; a novel fabrication method for photovoltaics

We studied the potential of using ultrafast laser pulses to process silicon for solar cell applications. Figure 1 shows the optical property of samples we fabricated. Commercial silicon solar cells cannot convert energy from long-wavelength light to electricity, while about 25% of the energy from sunlight resides in this wavelength region. On the other hand, the Mazur group found after laser processing of silicon in a chamber filled with sulfur containing gas, the light absorption is enhanced and the range of absorption is extended. Figure 2 shows that this technique is also effective on thin silicon films. 

The goals of our research are to study optical and electronic properties of samples fabricated using ultrafast lasers and design prototype solar cells with this material. We have made progress in the following three areas: (1) we identified laser parameters to independently control two laser processing outcomes: a) surface texturing to enhance absorption, b) laser doping to extend absorption spectral range (2) We extended laser fabrication to doping with solid thin films, which leads to a wider selection of dopant materials. (3) Our research shows that the silicon doped with high concentrations of sulfur belongs to a unique category of semiconductor where the conductivity is non-zero at temperatures approaching zero Kelvin.

(1)  We developed a technique to decouple the formation of surface roughness from the doping process. This was an essential step for characterizing the fundamental properties of this material and also enabled us to study the detail of the laser-material interactions. Furthermore, we worked with collaborators to integrate the laser-texturing technique into standard solar cell fabrication. We were able to perform laser texturing on 4um silicon thin films and show excellent light trapping properties approaching the Yablonovitch limit. With laser texturing, the same amount of sunlight can be absorbed by a thinner layer of silicon, and hence reducing the amount of material required for fabricating solar cells.

(2)  In addition to gaining knowledge on laser doping and texturing in gaseous environment, we studied doping with a thin film dopant precursor. Selenium-doped silicon is fabricated with fs-laser irradiation on a silicon wafer coated with a thin layer of selenium on top. While the optical properties of the selenium-doped silicon is similar to sulfur-doped silicon, we found that the laser-material interactions was significantly different, resulting in both different dopant distribution and electronic property.

(3)  The material properties of silicon doped with high concentrations of sulfur were not well known because of technical challenges in fabrication. Using ultrafast lasers, we were able to incorporate a high concentration of the sulfur atoms in silicon. We discovered the first documented metal-insulator transition in silicon driven by deep donor states (sulfur states). This is not only an important discovery for the field of intermediate band photovoltaics but also a useful contribution to the field of metal-insulator transitions in general. The doping technique is a potential route to intermediate band photovoltaic devices, which potentially could enhance the efficiency of a solar cell.

In conclusion, ultrafast laser processing of semiconductors provides two routes for photon management in photovoltaics, and our research advanced the techniques toward tailoring the material properties according to desired applications. We realized efficient light trapping for thin film solar cells via laser texturing and broaden the absorption range of silicon for an advanced photovoltaic concept through laser doping.
